Story of the Rescue.


Lieut.. Sweeney. who commanded the
rescuing party, reported to Capt Dey as
follows:


MY detachment, which consisted of one
corporal and six privates of Company H,
F, f3d Infantry, u. s. ", embarked at
Laguan on the steamer Lao-ang 7:3O am.
on the 18th Of April, 1900, enroute to Ca
tubig. where 1 had orders to resume COM
mand OF that garrison When we had reach
ed point about one mile from Catubig the
captain of the steamer was compelled to
stop his boat because the river was Block
ed with trees laShed together, and 1t was
impossible to proceed further without dam
aging the steamer 1 Immediately procured
all the axes available. and, lowering the
small boats, landed a corporal and four
men on each side of the river to stand
guard while 1 took the remainder of the
men to the blockade, which we destroyed
after much hard work A a hundred
feet high bordering on the river bank was
cut at the base so that a strong pull on
the ropes that were tied near the top (and
stretched across the river to the other
bank) would have formed a second blockade
almost as complete as the first. Those ropes
my men cut and destroyed In four nipa
houses on the banks of the river which had
been used as barracks by the insurgents 1
found over hundred pounds of fresh beef,
which l ordered to be thrown in the river,
and a hundred and fifty pounds of rice,
which l confiscated. 1 ordered those houses
burned and proceeded down the river.
When within quarter of a mile from Ca
tubig noise of an engagement could be
heard coming from that direction. and 1
ordered the captain of the steamer to run
his boat at full speed, and We steamed into
direction. My men Immediately returned
the fire. I had the small boats lowered
and prepared to load, after calling to the
men of the garrison to locate their position





lage were in ashes and other houses were
burning). Leaving three men on the steam
er with orders to hold it. Immediately pro-
ceeded to make landing. but before every
man was able to get into boats Corporal
White. Company F. was shot in the left
side and Private Farron. Company H. in
the calf of right leg. These two men were
put back on the steamer and we started for
shore. rifle fire coming from both sides Of
the river.


Joining the Garrison.


Eve fortunately made a landing and were
compelled to fight our way across open
ground to rescue our men. who were in
scme tall grass, distance of over seventy
five yards. Private Claucy. Company H.
was shot in the right instep in our advance
across this ground There was no cover OF
any kind that We could avail ourselves of
ard we were placed in tfe center of a circle
Of rifle r1re on open ground We could
have taken position I'm the grass (Where
we could not be seem. but by doing so we
could not command a view of the enemy s
movements. l sent two men In there 10
bury Privates Pomelow and Loose in the
trenches the men had made. while we
guarded them. the insurgents continuing
the fire and we returning 1t. AS soon as
could l got the wounded men and their
companions, thirteen in all, into the boats
and We boarded the steamer and returned.


THE streets of Catub.g were covered with
dead Insurgents, and l saw two floating
down the river. l should estimate their
loss was over two hundred The town was
fortified at every turn. particularly along
the river front. where the in>lrgcnts used
bags of rice. dirt and hemp for breast
works. On arriving at the place where We
had destroyed their blockade found that
they had made another attempt to block
our passage for they had made a rope of
long bamboo strips and cane, had attached
1t to the highest tree. and stretched 1t
across the river in the hope that tho smoke
stacks Of the steamer would pull 1t down
on U.S. but the rope was hurriodiy and poor
ly made and snapped.


81 strongly recommend the men OF my
detachment for the bravery and courage
and perseverance they displayed in their
when there was no support available for
them If they should lose. and absolutely no
retreat"

The War Department has just received
the report of Captain H NJ. Dey, 43d United
States Volunteer Infantry. of the remark
able experience of the garrison at Catubig,
in the Philippine Islands. in which a party
of thirty-one enlisted men of Company H
of that regiment maintained a successful
defense against an attacking force esti-
mated at over go insurgents. beginning
Sunday morning. April 10. and lasting until
rescued by a party under the command of
First Lieutenant Sweeney of that regiment.
on Thursday afternoon, April 49, during
which the party sustained a loss of eighteen
men killed and five wounded, while con-
servative estimate of the number of insur-
gents killed is upward of 200.


Catubig, at which this affair occurred, is
a small town on the Island of Samar.
which is the extreme easternmost island of
the Viscaya group, lying to the southeast
of LuZon, and about ten miles interior from
the extreme north coast of that island,
fifty-six miles from Catbalogan, the cap
ital of the province. and 1913 miles east
southeast from Manila, and had a popula-
ton at the time of the last Spanish census
oe 1855. The people of this island Eave
reputation of being of warlike disposition,
ferocious in their nature and exceedingly
treacherOus. Although the SpaniGrds had
local governor at Catbalogan. they never
were able to entirely suppress the people.
The trade was principally in hemp and CO.
coanut oil.


First Lieut.. Joseph T. Sweeney the Of
ficer who commanded the relief party is
native of New York city and served during
the Spanish-American war as second lieu
tenant of the 69th New York, with which
regiment he was Eonorab.y mustered out
January 81. 1899. and was commissioned
second lieutenant In the Add on the 14th
of August. 1892 and promoted to first lieu
tIN E.h of n1tN


Sergt. Dustin L. George, who commanded
the small party at CGtubig at the time of
the attack, Is a resident of Barre. VT, be-
ing son of Mrs Jennie NJ. Northup of No.
174 Merchant street. Barre, VT: he was n
married. Corporal Antkony ]. Carson. who.
after the death of Sergts. George and Hall.
succeeded to the command, and who is so
highly commended by Capt. Dey. is a resi-
dent of Maiden. Mass. at which place he
enlisted October 5, 1899, having formerly
served in Company F. Goth New York Vol
untcers. during the SpGZish-Amcrican war,
at which time he gave his nearest relative
as Mrs. David F. Carroll, No. 80 James
street, Maiden, Mass.


Capt. Dey's Report.


Captain Deys report is dated at Laguan.
April p, and is in part as follows:


about $50 am. Sunday, April Is, the
garrison was alarmed by shots coming
from the rear of the church on the left





prepared to resist the attack. Almost at
the same time a heavy fire was opened on
them from the hills on the right and left
and also from every available part of the
city which could be utilized by the insurgents.
This fire was kept up all day long, but the
garrison. with great courage and coolness.
met and returned the fire. with the result
that several insurgents were killed or
All during the night the firing was kept up,
but not quite so heavy as during the day.


About am. on Monday the firing was
resumed, and each hour went by 1t be-
came more general. AT about am. they
commenced firing a cannon which was
planted on the hill to the right of the bar
racks using cut nails and spikes for pro-
jectiles. Sergeant George who command
ed the garrison, ordered all the. fire from
the barracks to be concentrated on this can
non for the purpose of silencing 1t. and after
two voleys had been fired succeeded in
his purpose. Heavy rifle firing was kept up
all day and until about II pm. when 1t
lessened up until daylight Tuesday morn
ing, at which time the heavy firing was re-
sumed, about am. from the front and
across the river from the cannon. the cam
non having been changed to this new posi-
ton during the night: but few wel!-di-
rected shots from the garrison silenced 1t
for the time being. Up to this time but one
man of the garrison had been wounded,
Private Lee, who was shot on the left arm,
but a great number of insurgents had been
killed. some from their position in trees,
some from trying to charge the barracks.


About this time a large number of in
surgents had managed to make their way
into the church adjoining the barracks,
and were causing SO much trouble that 1t
became necessary to silence them Ser
geant George called for ten men to charge
the church and drive them out. The men
Immediately responded. and under terri
bly, heavy fire from all sides they succeeded
in getting in. and finding nearly hundred
insurgents there Immediately poured sew
III ;,to tt,ayV, iycr
Der. By this time all the firing was CEN
tered the church. and Sergeant George,
finding that to remain longer would be
fatal to his little band. retreated back to
the barracks. This brave deed was accom-
plished without the loss of a single man.
The firing became SO heavy and the terri
BILE strain on the men so great from their
long and continuous fighting that 1t re-
quired them to put forth their greatest ef-
forts to meet this heavy fire.


The Barracks Fired.


about this time the insurgents had man
aged to regain the church. and from the
windows made several unsuccessful efforts
to set fire to the barracks. Finally they
managed to throw some hemp saturated
with oil against the building and succeeded
In setting fire to It. All efforts to subdue
this fire proved unavailing, and when the
building became untenable. the heat being
50 intense, the garrison hastily decided the
only course open to them was to make
dash for the river and attempt to get
across. hoping to intrench themselves on
the opposite shore. They destroyed every
thing which would be of value to the In
surgents, divided the ammunition between
them. cut hole in the floor and dropped
through one at time to the basement be-
low. When all of them had gotten through
they made a rush for the river. Some OF
them were killed before they reached the
river. Corporal Carson. with fifteen men.
Immediately started to build trench, using
their bayonets to dig with. The rest Of the
men attempted to cross the river. but were
all killed while getting in the boat


Held Trench for Two Days.


For two days Corporal Carson and his
squad held this trench. fighting all the
time against great odds and having two
men killed and three wounded. one OF
whom. Sergeant Hall. has since died. until
he was finally rescued on Thursday morn
ing by Lieutenant Sweeney and his de-
tachment. His report accompanies this
one and shows the difficulties which he en-
countered in the rescue. conservative
estimate of the number of insurgents killed
is upward of 900. but have no record Of the
number of wounded. The loss we sustained
Is eighteen killed and five wounded, one of
whom has since died. l also lost q large
amount of ordnance stores. quartermaster
and commissary supplies, of which 1 will
submit certificate to the officers Of those
departments.

90

circumstances, de all Of them acts which
call forth the highest Qzafse for their zeal
worth and courage of the American sol
der"


The Casualties.


The following Is the list Of casualties Of
this engagement:


Killed-Sergeants Dustin L. George, Will
liam J. Hall. Corporals Herbert Edwards,
Jdln F. ]. Hamilton. Cook Burton E. Hess,
Musician Burton R.Wagner, Privates Treff-
lie Pomelow, Otto B. Loose, Stephen Apper-
II, Joseph Noeil. John E. Kuhn. Ralph H.
Zim, Edward Bramen. Chester A A. Conk-
lin, Walter E. Collins. Joseph ]. Kerins,
Henry Dumas. Philip Sailing and George A
Slack.


Wounded-Corporal Lester Rushworth.
shot in right leg, and Privates Harry C.
Lee. shot in left arm: Michael ]. Faron.
shot in calf Of right leg: Corporal White of
Company F, shot near right hip, slight"


Story of the Rescue.


Lieut.. Sweeney. who commanded the
rescuing party, reported to Capt Dey as
follows:


MY detachment, which consisted of one
corporal and six privates of Company H,
F, f3d Infantry, u. s. ", embarked at
Laguan on the steamer Lao-ang 7:3O am.
on the 18th Of April, 1900, enroute to Ca
tubig. where 1 had orders to resume COM
mand OF that garrison When we had reach
ed point about one mile from Catubig the
captain of the steamer was compelled to
stop his boat because the river was Block
ed with trees laShed together, and 1t was
impossible to proceed further without dam
aging the steamer 1 Immediately procured
all the axes available. and, lowering the
small boats, landed a corporal and four
men on each side of the river to stand
guard while 1 took the remainder of the
men to the blockade, which we destroyed
after much hard work A a hundred
feet high bordering on the river bank was
cut at the base so that a strong pull on
the ropes that were tied near the top (and
stretched across the river to the other
bank) would have formed a second blockade
almost as complete as the first. Those ropes
my men cut and destroyed In four nipa
houses on the banks of the river which had
been used as barracks by the insurgents 1
found over hundred pounds of fresh beef,
which l ordered to be thrown in the river,
and a hundred and fifty pounds of rice,
which l confiscated. 1 ordered those houses
burned and proceeded down the river.
When within quarter of a mile from Ca
tubig noise of an engagement could be
heard coming from that direction. and 1
ordered the captain of the steamer to run
his boat at full speed, and We steamed into
direction. My men Immediately returned
the fire. I had the small boats lowered
and prepared to load, after calling to the
men of the garrison to locate their position





lage were in ashes and other houses were
burning). Leaving three men on the steam
er with orders to hold it. Immediately pro-
ceeded to make landing. but before every
man was able to get into boats Corporal
White. Company F. was shot in the left
side and Private Farron. Company H. in
the calf of right leg. These two men were
put back on the steamer and we started for
shore. rifle fire coming from both sides Of
the river.


Joining the Garrison.


Eve fortunately made a landing and were
compelled to fight our way across open
ground to rescue our men. who were in
scme tall grass, distance of over seventy
five yards. Private Claucy. Company H.
was shot in the right instep in our advance
across this ground There was no cover OF
any kind that We could avail ourselves of
ard we were placed in tfe center of a circle
Of rifle r1re on open ground We could
have taken position I'm the grass (Where
we could not be seem. but by doing so we
could not command a view of the enemy s
movements. l sent two men In there 10
bury Privates Pomelow and Loose in the
trenches the men had made. while we
guarded them. the insurgents continuing
the fire and we returning 1t. AS soon as
could l got the wounded men and their
companions, thirteen in all, into the boats
and We boarded the steamer and returned.


THE streets of Catub.g were covered with
dead Insurgents, and l saw two floating
down the river. l should estimate their
loss was over two hundred The town was
fortified at every turn. particularly along
the river front. where the in>lrgcnts used
bags of rice. dirt and hemp for breast
works. On arriving at the place where We
had destroyed their blockade found that
they had made another attempt to block
our passage for they had made a rope of
long bamboo strips and cane, had attached
1t to the highest tree. and stretched 1t
across the river in the hope that tho smoke
stacks Of the steamer would pull 1t down
on U.S. but the rope was hurriodiy and poor
ly made and snapped.


81 strongly recommend the men OF my
detachment for the bravery and courage
and perseverance they displayed in their
when there was no support available for
them If they should lose. and absolutely no
retreat"

full articles.headline:
A BRAVE DEFENSE.
Gallant Work of Volunteers in the


Philippines.
WERE ODFNUMBERED TWENTY TO ONE
HeroicaIIy Resisted Attacks for
Five Days.
STORY OF TIL ETR RESCTJE

7BRE ODTNUMBERED TWENTY TO ONE

STORY OF THEIR RESCUE
full articles.article:
The War Department has just received
the report of Captain H NJ. Dey, 43d United
States Volunteer Infantry. of the remark
able experience of the garrison at Catubig,
in the Philippine Islands. in which a party
of thirty-one enlisted men of Company H
of that regiment maintained a successful
defense against an attacking force esti-
mated at over go insurgents. beginning
Sunday morning. April 10. and lasting until
rescued by a party under the command of
First Lieutenant Sweeney of that regiment.
on Thursday afternoon, April 49, during
which the party sustained a loss of eighteen
men killed and five wounded, while con-
servative estimate of the number of insur-
gents killed is upward of 200.


Catubig, at which this affair occurred, is
a small town on the Island of Samar.
which is the extreme easternmost island of
the Viscaya group, lying to the southeast
of LuZon, and about ten miles interior from
the extreme north coast of that island,
fifty-six miles from Catbalogan, the cap
ital of the province. and 1913 miles east
southeast from Manila, and had a popula-
ton at the time of the last Spanish census
oe 1855. The people of this island Eave
reputation of being of warlike disposition,
ferocious in their nature and exceedingly
treacherOus. Although the SpaniGrds had
local governor at Catbalogan. they never
were able to entirely suppress the people.
The trade was principally in hemp and CO.
coanut oil.


First Lieut.. Joseph T. Sweeney the Of
ficer who commanded the relief party is
native of New York city and served during
the Spanish-American war as second lieu
tenant of the 69th New York, with which
regiment he was Eonorab.y mustered out
January 81. 1899. and was commissioned
second lieutenant In the Add on the 14th
of August. 1892 and promoted to first lieu
tIN E.h of n1tN


Sergt. Dustin L. George, who commanded
the small party at CGtubig at the time of
the attack, Is a resident of Barre. VT, be-
ing son of Mrs Jennie NJ. Northup of No.
174 Merchant street. Barre, VT: he was n
married. Corporal Antkony ]. Carson. who.
after the death of Sergts. George and Hall.
succeeded to the command, and who is so
highly commended by Capt. Dey. is a resi-
dent of Maiden. Mass. at which place he
enlisted October 5, 1899, having formerly
served in Company F. Goth New York Vol
untcers. during the SpGZish-Amcrican war,
at which time he gave his nearest relative
as Mrs. David F. Carroll, No. 80 James
street, Maiden, Mass.


Capt. Dey's Report.


Captain Deys report is dated at Laguan.
April p, and is in part as follows:


about $50 am. Sunday, April Is, the
garrison was alarmed by shots coming
from the rear of the church on the left





prepared to resist the attack. Almost at
the same time a heavy fire was opened on
them from the hills on the right and left
and also from every available part of the
city which could be utilized by the insurgents.
This fire was kept up all day long, but the
garrison. with great courage and coolness.
met and returned the fire. with the result
that several insurgents were killed or
All during the night the firing was kept up,
but not quite so heavy as during the day.


About am. on Monday the firing was
resumed, and each hour went by 1t be-
came more general. AT about am. they
commenced firing a cannon which was
planted on the hill to the right of the bar
racks using cut nails and spikes for pro-
jectiles. Sergeant George who command
ed the garrison, ordered all the. fire from
the barracks to be concentrated on this can
non for the purpose of silencing 1t. and after
two voleys had been fired succeeded in
his purpose. Heavy rifle firing was kept up
all day and until about II pm. when 1t
lessened up until daylight Tuesday morn
ing, at which time the heavy firing was re-
sumed, about am. from the front and
across the river from the cannon. the cam
non having been changed to this new posi-
ton during the night: but few wel!-di-
rected shots from the garrison silenced 1t
for the time being. Up to this time but one
man of the garrison had been wounded,
Private Lee, who was shot on the left arm,
but a great number of insurgents had been
killed. some from their position in trees,
some from trying to charge the barracks.


About this time a large number of in
surgents had managed to make their way
into the church adjoining the barracks,
and were causing SO much trouble that 1t
became necessary to silence them Ser
geant George called for ten men to charge
the church and drive them out. The men
Immediately responded. and under terri
bly, heavy fire from all sides they succeeded
in getting in. and finding nearly hundred
insurgents there Immediately poured sew
III ;,to tt,ayV, iycr
Der. By this time all the firing was CEN
tered the church. and Sergeant George,
finding that to remain longer would be
fatal to his little band. retreated back to
the barracks. This brave deed was accom-
plished without the loss of a single man.
The firing became SO heavy and the terri
BILE strain on the men so great from their
long and continuous fighting that 1t re-
quired them to put forth their greatest ef-
forts to meet this heavy fire.


The Barracks Fired.


about this time the insurgents had man
aged to regain the church. and from the
windows made several unsuccessful efforts
to set fire to the barracks. Finally they
managed to throw some hemp saturated
with oil against the building and succeeded
In setting fire to It. All efforts to subdue
this fire proved unavailing, and when the
building became untenable. the heat being
50 intense, the garrison hastily decided the
only course open to them was to make
dash for the river and attempt to get
across. hoping to intrench themselves on
the opposite shore. They destroyed every
thing which would be of value to the In
surgents, divided the ammunition between
them. cut hole in the floor and dropped
through one at time to the basement be-
low. When all of them had gotten through
they made a rush for the river. Some OF
them were killed before they reached the
river. Corporal Carson. with fifteen men.
Immediately started to build trench, using
their bayonets to dig with. The rest Of the
men attempted to cross the river. but were
all killed while getting in the boat


Held Trench for Two Days.


For two days Corporal Carson and his
squad held this trench. fighting all the
time against great odds and having two
men killed and three wounded. one OF
whom. Sergeant Hall. has since died. until
he was finally rescued on Thursday morn
ing by Lieutenant Sweeney and his de-
tachment. His report accompanies this
one and shows the difficulties which he en-
countered in the rescue. conservative
estimate of the number of insurgents killed
is upward of 900. but have no record Of the
number of wounded. The loss we sustained
Is eighteen killed and five wounded, one of
whom has since died. l also lost q large
amount of ordnance stores. quartermaster
and commissary supplies, of which 1 will
submit certificate to the officers Of those
departments.
